<task>
HELP WITH MY MCP SERVER:
Connecting VS Code to MCP (Model Context Protocol) Server

Connecting VS Code to an MCP Server: Troubleshooting & Alternatives
Understanding the ‚ÄúNot Connected‚Äù Issue
When VS Code‚Äôs MCP integration shows a red ‚ÄúNot connected‚Äù status, it means the editor failed to establish a link to your MCP server. This can happen even if the server is running, due to misconfiguration or bugs. Common causes include mismatched connection types (e.g. treating a remote server as local), the server process failing to start, or platform-specific issues. For example, some MCP servers that rely on native modules have known installation problems on Windows, causing the server to silently exit and never register as connected. VS Code‚Äôs MCP support is still in preview, so a ‚ÄúNot connected‚Äù error can also result from unpolished features (one GitHub issue notes SSE connections failing with a fetch failed error in VS Code 1.99
github.com
). Understanding why the connection fails is the first step to a solution.
Diagnosing Connection Problems in VS Code
1. Check VS Code‚Äôs MCP Output: VS Code provides logs for MCP server processes. In the Copilot Chat panel, click the error indicator and choose ‚ÄúShow Output,‚Äù or run the ‚ÄúMCP: List Servers‚Äù command and select ‚ÄúShow Output‚Äù for the server. These logs often reveal the issue. For instance, an error like ‚Äúspawn uvx ENOENT‚Äù indicates the command wasn‚Äôt found in PATH (in this case, uvx was missing, meaning the MCP server‚Äôs runtime wasn‚Äôt accessible). Similarly, an error about ‚Äúfetch failed‚Äù for an SSE URL means VS Code couldn‚Äôt reach the endpoint
github.com
 ‚Äì possibly due to a network issue or a VS Code bug on that transport. 2. Verify the MCP Server Process: Ensure the MCP server is actually running and listening. If you configured a stdio server (one that runs as a local process), check your system‚Äôs process list or terminal for any crash output. If it exits immediately (e.g. due to a build failure on startup), VS Code will report ‚ÄúNot connected.‚Äù In one case with Supabase‚Äôs MCP server on Windows, a PostgreSQL query library failed to build, causing the server to never stay active. The solution there was to use a different environment (WSL) or await a patch to that package. If you‚Äôre using an SSE or HTTP server (hosted remotely), try hitting the endpoint outside VS Code ‚Äì for example, using curl or a browser. You should see an SSE stream or HTTP response. The MCP CLI tool (discussed below) is also handy for testing this. 3. Double-Check Configuration: Open your MCP config (either in .vscode/mcp.json for the workspace or your user settings.json under the "mcp.servers" key) to ensure it matches your server setup. Key fields are the type of connection and the command or URL. For a local process, use "type": "stdio" with a correct command and args; for a remote endpoint, use "type": "sse" (or "http" if using streamable HTTP) with a url field. An example from Supabase‚Äôs docs shows a typical config for VS Code on Windows using a Node process:
json
Copy
Edit
{
  "inputs": [
    { "type": "promptString", "id": "supabase-access-token", "description": "Supabase personal access token", "password": true }
  ],
  "servers": {
    "supabase": {
      "command": "npx",
      "args": ["-y", "@supabase/mcp-server-supabase@latest"],
      "env": { "SUPABASE_ACCESS_TOKEN": "${input:supabase-access-token}" }
    }
  }
}
Here the server is launched via npx (pulling the latest package) and expects a token at runtime
supabase.com
. If your server is instead hosted (e.g. an MCP server running in the cloud or via GitHub Actions), your config should point to its URL with "type": "sse" and a "url" ‚Äì for example:
json
Copy
Edit
"servers": {
  "my-cloud-mcp": {
    "type": "sse",
    "url": "https://<my-server-domain>/sse"
  }
}
Make sure the URL and path are exactly correct (many MCP servers expose an /sse endpoint for Server-Sent Events). If authentication or custom headers are required, include them in the config under a "headers" field as needed
github.com
forum.cursor.com
. 4. Connection Workflow in VS Code: Remember that after configuring, you typically need to start the server in VS Code and switch Copilot into Agent mode. In VS Code‚Äôs chat view, select ‚ÄúAgent‚Äù from the mode dropdown (this is GitHub Copilot‚Äôs agentic mode which uses MCP). If the server is properly configured, a ‚ÄúStart‚Äù button should appear next to it in the MCP servers list; click that to launch the connection. VS Code will then prompt for any input (like the token) and attempt to connect. A successful connection is indicated by a green status dot in the MCP servers list (as opposed to the red ‚Äúnot connected‚Äù icon). If you never see a green indicator or the tool list remains empty, proceed to the alternatives below.
Alternative Ways to Connect to the MCP Server
When the VS Code extension isn‚Äôt cooperating, you have other avenues to interact with your MCP server:
Use the MCP CLI (Inspector): The community has a command-line tool called mcp-cli (by wong2) which can act as an MCP client in your terminal. This tool lets you connect to any MCP server and invoke its tools or list them, independent of VS Code. For example, you can connect to a running server via its URL:
bash
Copy
Edit
npx @wong2/mcp-cli --sse http://localhost:8000/sse
This would attach to an SSE server on port 8000 and allow you to send tool requests interactively. If your MCP server uses HTTP instead of SSE, --url http://.../mcp can be used similarly. Using mcp-cli is a great way to verify your server is functional. If the CLI can successfully list tools or execute a sample tool, but VS Code still can‚Äôt connect, the problem lies with the VS Code extension rather than the server.
Direct REST/SSE Calls: MCP is a protocol, but many servers (especially those running in cloud environments) expose standard endpoints. If your server has an HTTP API (some advertise a /mcp or similar endpoint that accepts JSON requests, or use SSE for streaming), you can try interacting with it using general tools. For instance, you might POST a tool invocation JSON to the HTTP endpoint using curl or a REST client, or use an SSE client library to subscribe to an SSE stream. This approach is more manual, but useful for debugging: if you get a valid response from the server via HTTP, you know the server side is fine. (Refer to your MCP server‚Äôs documentation for the exact API format if available ‚Äì e.g. the Model Context Protocol spec defines how tool requests should be structured.)
Run a Local Proxy/Gateway: If your MCP server is remote and VS Code‚Äôs MCP client doesn‚Äôt support direct connection (or has a bug, as with SSE on certain versions
github.com
), you can employ a proxy. One strategy is to run a small local MCP proxy that connects out to your server, then have VS Code connect to the proxy via stdio. For example, the community tool ‚Äúmcp-proxy‚Äù acts as an stdio-to-SSE transport gateway. You would run mcp-proxy pointing at your server‚Äôs SSE URL; it opens a local stdio interface that VS Code can start as if it were a local server. This essentially tunnels the SSE connection through a local process. While this adds a bit of complexity, it can work around limitations in the VS Code extension.
Try a Different Client/Extension: If the goal is to use the MCP server‚Äôs functionality (tools) and not necessarily through VS Code, consider alternate clients:
Cline (VS Code extension): Cline is an open-source Copilot/Cursor alternative that runs in VS Code and supports MCP servers. It has its own MCP configuration (slightly different JSON format). Some users have found that Cline can connect to the same MCP servers that VS Code‚Äôs built-in chat cannot, possibly due to different implementation. Given that the Supabase guide explicitly lists Cline as supported, it might be worth installing Cline and configuring the server there (as shown in Supabase‚Äôs docs).
Cursor (standalone IDE): Cursor is another IDE that supports MCP. If you have it, you can add the MCP server in Cursor‚Äôs settings (it accepts similar config with type and command/URL). This isn‚Äôt a solution for VS Code per se, but if you urgently need to use the server‚Äôs tools, Cursor could be a stop-gap until VS Code is resolved.
Anthropic Claude Desktop: If your MCP server is intended for use with Claude (some MCP servers are built to augment Claude‚Äôs abilities), the Claude Desktop app can load them as well. It uses a config file format akin to VS Code‚Äôs. This might be relevant if you are specifically working with Anthropic‚Äôs model.
Other IDEs like Windsurf (Codium) or Zed also support MCP servers. In short, the MCP server itself is IDE-agnostic, so don‚Äôt feel locked into the VS Code extension if that piece isn‚Äôt working.
Configuration Tips and Workarounds
If you suspect the issue is with VS Code‚Äôs extension implementation, here are some tips and tweaks:
Match the Transport Type: Ensure that the type in your config matches how the server is meant to be accessed. Use stdio for servers you run locally (via a command), sse for long-lived Server-Sent Events connections, or http for one-shot HTTP endpoints
code.visualstudio.com
. A common mistake is trying to use a remote MCP endpoint as if it were a local process ‚Äì in that case VS Code might show ‚ÄúStarting‚Ä¶‚Äù forever or ‚ÄúNot connected.‚Äù Conversely, if you set type: "sse" with a URL but your server isn‚Äôt actually providing an SSE stream, VS Code will fail to connect. Double-check the server‚Äôs README for how it‚Äôs meant to be launched. For example, GitHub‚Äôs official MCP server is designed to run as a Docker container locally (stdio), whereas something like a Supabase MCP server could theoretically be self-hosted and exposed over SSE.
Use WSL or Containers on Windows: If you‚Äôre on Windows and the MCP server installation is failing, leverage WSL (Windows Subsystem for Linux) or Docker. As reported in community forums, many folks got stubborn servers working by running them in WSL and pointing the MCP client to that environment. You can modify the VS Code config to launch the server via WSL ‚Äì for example, set the command to "wsl" and pass the Linux path to your server script or npx command as arguments. This forces VS Code to start the process in the WSL context. (Similarly, using a Dockerized server is an option: for instance, the GitHub MCP server uses a Docker command; just avoid the -d flag so it runs attached.) Ensure any required environment variables or tokens are accessible in that environment. Using WSL/Docker adds a layer, but it circumvents Windows-specific issues like missing build tools or incompatible dependencies.
Environment and Path Issues: The VS Code process launching your server may not have the same PATH or env as your normal shell. The ‚Äúspawn ENOENT‚Äù errors usually mean it couldn‚Äôt find an executable. If you used a shorthand command (like uvx or npm), try using the full path or ensuring the tool is globally installed. You can also prefix the command with a shell invocation to load your profile. For example, on Windows/WSL you might use:
json
Copy
Edit
"command": "bash",
"args": ["-i", "-c", "npx -y @supabase/mcp-server-supabase@latest"]
The -i -c ensures an interactive shell which loads ~/.bashrc, so your nvm or other setup is in place (this was needed in one user‚Äôs case to get Node and node-gyp on the right path). On macOS/Linux, similar tactics apply if using a login shell makes a difference. The key is to replicate the environment where the server runs successfully.
Keep VS Code Updated: Since MCP support is evolving, make sure you‚Äôre on the latest VS Code version (1.99+ for MCP). Check the VS Code issue tracker for MCP-related bugs ‚Äì for example, the SSE connection bug
github.com
 might be fixed in a newer release. If you find an open issue matching your problem, you might glean workarounds from the discussion or know that a fix is incoming. As of April 2025, GitHub publicly released their MCP server and the ecosystem is moving fast
docs.github.com
, so improvements are frequent.
Testing with Minimal Setup: If possible, test with a simple known-good MCP server to isolate the issue. For instance, try adding a trivial MCP server like the ‚ÄúFetch‚Äù example (which just fetches web content) or a small weather server. If VS Code connects to that, then your MCP client (VS Code) is working and the problem lies in the specific server. If even simple servers don‚Äôt connect, then VS Code or your environment is at fault. This A/B test can save time.
References & Resources
VS Code MCP Documentation (Preview) ‚Äì Official guide on enabling MCP, adding servers, and troubleshooting in VS Code. This covers the basics of .vscode/mcp.json and how to view logs.
Supabase MCP Guide ‚Äì Example configuration for connecting VS Code (Copilot) to a Supabase MCP server
supabase.com
, with notes on expected behavior. Also includes tips for other clients (Cursor, Cline) which can be informative.
GitHub MCP Server Repo ‚Äì GitHub‚Äôs own MCP server (for GitHub API integration) with setup instructions. Useful as a reference for Docker-based servers.
Community Discussions and Issues: Several GitHub issues and forum threads document ‚Äúnot connected‚Äù problems. For instance, Supabase‚Äôs MCP issue tracker has a Windows thread concluding that a dependency needed an update, and the VS Code issue tracker has an open issue for SSE connection errors
github.com
. These can provide insight if your scenario is similar.
MCP CLI and Tooling: The mcp-cli inspector on GitHub and the awesome-mcp-servers list
github.com
 (which catalogs tools like mcp-client and mcp-proxy) are great resources if you seek alternative clients or utilities to bridge connections. There is an entire emerging ecosystem around MCP ‚Äì if the VS Code extension isn‚Äôt meeting your needs, these tools might fill the gap.
By systematically diagnosing the issue and leveraging these alternative methods, you should be able to connect to your MCP server or at least pinpoint why VS Code‚Äôs extension is failing. Remember that MCP integration is new ‚Äì don‚Äôt hesitate to raise issues on the relevant GitHub repo with logs, as this helps the maintainers improve the tools. Good luck, and happy coding with your MCP-enhanced workflow!
</task>

<content>@echo off
echo ===== MCP CONNECTION TROUBLESHOOTER =====
echo.

if %ERRORLEVEL% NEQ 0 (
  echo Failed to install MCP CLI tool. Please check your internet connection.
  exit /b 1
)
echo MCP CLI tool installed successfully.
echo.

echo Step 2: Testing if an MCP server is already running...
node mcp-connection-test.js
echo.

echo Step 3: Starting a test session with the Filesystem MCP server...
echo This will attempt to connect directly to the server using the MCP CLI.
echo Press Ctrl+C to exit when done testing.
echo.
echo Starting connection...
call npx -y @wong2/mcp-cli --stdio "npx -y @modelcontextprotocol/server-filesystem c:/Users/jason/Desktop/tori/kha"

echo.
echo Troubleshooting completed. If the above command connected successfully,
echo but VS Code still shows "Not connected", you might need to:
echo.
echo 1. Restart VS Code
echo 2. Check VS Code's Output panel for MCP errors (Ctrl+Shift+U)
echo 3. Make sure your settings.json's mcpServers section has the correct configuration
echo 4. Update VS Code to the latest version (at least 1.99+ for MCP support)
</content>

<content># MCP Server Connection Troubleshooting Guide

This guide will help you diagnose and fix connection issues with MCP (Model Context Protocol) servers in VS Code and Cline.

## Quick Solutions

1. **For Cline extension**: The filesystem server was disabled in your Cline settings. We've already fixed this by changing `"disabled": true` to `"disabled": false` in your Cline MCP settings file.

2. **For VS Code**: Ensure your MCP server is properly configured and running. Use the tools provided in this guide to diagnose connection issues.

## Diagnostic Tools

We've created two diagnostic tools to help troubleshoot MCP server connections:

1. **mcp-connection-test.js**: Checks if your MCP servers are running and accessible.
2. **test-mcp-connection.bat**: A comprehensive troubleshooter that:
   - Installs the MCP CLI tool
   - Checks for running MCP servers
   - Attempts to connect directly to the filesystem server

## Common Issues and Solutions

### 1. "Not Connected" Status in VS Code

**Possible causes:**
- MCP server is not running
- MCP server configuration is incorrect
- VS Code extension has a bug
- Server process failing to start or crashing

**Solutions:**
- Run `test-mcp-connection.bat` to diagnose the issue
- Check VS Code's output panel for MCP errors:
  - Run the command "MCP: List Servers"
  - Click "Show Output" for your server
- Ensure your MCP configuration has the correct transportType (stdio/sse/http)
- Restart VS Code

### 2. MCP Server Process Exits Immediately

**Possible causes:**
- Missing dependencies
- Configuration errors
- Build failures

**Solutions:**
- Check for errors in the VS Code output panel
- Try running the server manually using `npx -y @modelcontextprotocol/server-filesystem c:/Users/jason/Desktop/tori/kha`
- Look for error messages in the console

### 3. Cline Extension Not Connecting

**Solutions:**
- We've already fixed the disabled flag in your Cline settings
- Restart VS Code to apply the changes
- Make sure Cline is using the latest version of the MCP server

## Configuration Reference

### VS Code (Native) MCP Configuration
```json
"mcpServers": {
  "memory": {
    "command": "npx",
    "args": ["-y", "@modelcontextprotocol/server-memory"]
  },
  "github.com/modelcontextprotocol/servers/tree/main/src/filesystem": {
    "command": "npx",
    "args": ["-y", "@modelcontextprotocol/server-filesystem", "c:/Users/jason/Desktop/tori/kha"]
  },
  "github": {
    "command": "npx",
    "args": ["-y", "@modelcontextprotocol/server-github"],
    "env": {
      "GITHUB_PERSONAL_ACCESS_TOKEN": "your-token-here"
    }
  }
}
```

### Cline MCP Configuration
```json
"mcpServers": {
  "github.com/modelcontextprotocol/servers/tree/main/src/filesystem": {
    "autoApprove": [],
    "disabled": false,
    "timeout": 60,
    "command": "npx",
    "args": [
      "-y",
      "@modelcontextprotocol/server-filesystem",
      "c:/Users/jason/Desktop/tori/kha"
    ],
    "transportType": "stdio"
  }
}
```

## Alternative Connection Methods

If VS Code or Cline still won't connect to your MCP server, try these alternatives:

1. **Use MCP CLI directly**:
   ```
   npx @wong2/mcp-cli --stdio "npx -y @modelcontextprotocol/server-filesystem c:/Users/jason/Desktop/tori/kha"
   ```
   
2. **Try a different client**:
   - Cursor IDE
   - Claude Desktop App
   - Anthropic's web interfaces

3. **Run in WSL** (if on Windows):
   - Some MCP servers work better in WSL due to native module dependencies
   - Configure your MCP server to run via WSL in the settings

## Next Steps

1. Run `test-mcp-connection.bat` to diagnose any remaining issues
2. Restart VS Code to apply the configuration changes
3. Check that both VS Code and Cline can connect to your MCP servers
4. If issues persist, examine the error logs for specific error messages
</content>
